articles.headline: Michigan Naming Fiscal Manager to Help Detroit
articles.snippet: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan announced on Friday that the city of Detroit is so snarled in financial woes that the state must appoint an emergency manager to lead it out of disaster.
articles.abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan announced on Friday that the city of Detroit is so snarled in financial woes that the state must appoint an emergency manager to lead it out of disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Over the fierce protests of this city’s elected leaders, the State of Michigan plans to send an emergency manager to repair the deeply troubled finances of Detroit, one of the largest cities ever to reach such a dire point or to face such a level of oversight.

articles.headline: Judge Cuts Sum Owed to Apple Over Patents
articles.snippet: A federal judge lessened the blow from Apple’s legal victory in a patent case over Samsung, lopping more than 40 percent off the damages.
articles.abstract: A federal judge lessened the blow from Apple’s legal victory in a patent case over Samsung, lopping more than 40 percent off the damages.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

articles.headline: Fighting the Insurer Over Hurricane Sandy Damage
articles.snippet: A Brooklyn couple say their insurance company will pay $49,000 for home repairs, while an adjuster they hired put the figure needed at $200,000.
articles.abstract: A Brooklyn couple say their insurance company will pay $49,000 for home repairs, while an adjuster they hired put the figure needed at $200,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Sandy moving in, Andrea and Stephen Kondaks gathered candles, water and flashlights, and then put on their fishing waders. There was nothing left to do but wait, and watch, as the oily water slowly seeped into the hallway of their house, two and a half blocks from the bay in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

articles.headline: Way to Reach Kim Jong-un? Follow the Ball
articles.snippet: Dennis Rodman and his traveling companions are now the only Americans known to have met the North Korean leader since he took power more than a year ago.
articles.abstract: Dennis Rodman and his traveling companions are now the only Americans known to have met the North Korean leader since he took power more than a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Landing an audience with Kim Jong-un, the leader of one of the world’s most reclusive countries, is not easy.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Penney’s and Macy’s Battle Over Martha Stewart Products
articles.snippet: A trial between J.C. Penney and Macy’s shows how competitive the middle-market home goods category is and how much a brand like Martha Stewart can matter.
articles.abstract: A trial between J.C. Penney and Macy’s shows how competitive the middle-market home goods category is and how much a brand like Martha Stewart can matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest names in retail are fighting over Martha Stewart.

articles.headline: From Elephants’ Mouths, an Illicit Trail to China
articles.snippet: Trade in elephant tusks continues to thrive in China, even as conservation groups call on Beijing to do more to crack down on the slaughter of African elephants.
articles.abstract: Trade in elephant tusks continues to thrive in China, even as conservation groups call on Beijing to do more to crack down on the slaughter of African elephants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUZHAI, China — Chinese investors have anointed it “white gold.” Carvers and collectors prefer the term “organic gemstone.” Smugglers, however, use a gruesomely straightforward name for the recently harvested African elephant tusks that find their way to this remote trading outpost on the Vietnamese border.

articles.headline: Classic Toys Redesigned to Traverse Generations
articles.snippet: To Hasbro, there is no one too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.
articles.abstract: To Hasbro, there is no one too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Hasbro, no one is too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.

articles.headline: A Divide on Voting Rights in a Town Where Blood Spilled
articles.snippet: McComb, Miss., was a battleground in the war for voting rights in the South. Residents disagree over whether their state and eight others need federal approval for changes.
articles.abstract: McComb, Miss., was a battleground in the war for voting rights in the South. Residents disagree over whether their state and eight others need federal approval for changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: McCOMB, Miss. — In the refined air of the United States Supreme Court, the questions posed by justices on Wednesday seemed so big as to be unanswerable: Are parts of the Voting Rights Act an unfair infringement on state sovereignty? How different is the South these days from other regions, and from itself in bloody years past?

articles.headline: Promises, Promises at the New York Fed
articles.snippet: A secret agreement shows that in exchange for $43 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York agreed to testify on Bank of America’s behalf in a battle over fraud claims.
articles.abstract: A secret agreement shows that in exchange for $43 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York agreed to testify on Bank of America’s behalf in a battle over fraud claims.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, I wrote a column about a secret agreement struck in July 2012 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Bank of America. The existence of the confidential deal was disclosed recently in court filings, which showed the New York Fed releasing Bank of America from all fraud claims on mortgage securities the Fed had bought as part of the government’s rescue of the American International Group in 2008.

articles.headline: Alaska Airlines, Flying Above an Industry’s Troubles
articles.snippet: Born in rugged terrain, Alaska Airlines fortified itself — and has resisted the cycle of bankruptcy and mergers buffeting its industry.
articles.abstract: Born in rugged terrain, Alaska Airlines fortified itself — and has resisted the cycle of bankruptcy and mergers buffeting its industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLYING over Alaska in the wintertime is a spectacular experience. At 35,000 feet, the state’s rugged beauty unfolds, a succession of white mountain peaks against steel-blue skies, icy lakes and frozen rivers that snake as far as the eye can see. It’s an awesome sight, wild and pristine, that glows in a thousand hues of red, orange and pink when the sun sets against the horizon.

articles.headline: Selling the Home Brand: A Look Inside an Elite JPMorgan Unit
articles.snippet: While financial advisers at other firms are typically free to offer a variety of investments, JPMorgan pressures brokers to sell the bank’s own products, current and former employees say.
articles.abstract: While financial advisers at other firms are typically free to offer a variety of investments, JPMorgan pressures brokers to sell the bank’s own products, current and former employees say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everything is scripted for the brokers in an elite group at JPMorgan Chase: the sales pitches; the personal voice mail message; even the preferred desk candy, Glitterati Fruit & Berry.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Think New York Is Costly? In New Delhi, Seedy Goes for 8 Figures
articles.snippet: Real estate prices in New Delhi, especially for bungalows built during the British Raj, are among the world’s highest.
articles.abstract: Real estate prices in New Delhi, especially for bungalows built during the British Raj, are among the world’s highest.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The fading bungalow at 38 Amrita Shergil Marg does not immediately shout real estate bling.

articles.headline: Cuts to Achieve Goal for Deficit, but Toll Is High
articles.snippet: The latest budget impasse ushered in a new round of austerity, with the nation facing reduced federal services, canceled contracts and layoffs from cuts that reduce projected deficits but could hamper the economy.
articles.abstract: The latest budget impasse ushered in a new round of austerity, with the nation facing reduced federal services, canceled contracts and layoffs from cuts that reduce projected deficits but could hamper the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The latest budget impasse ushered in a new round of austerity on Saturday, with the nation facing reduced federal services, canceled contracts, job furloughs and layoffs.

articles.headline: Long Border, Endless Struggle
articles.snippet: Is the United States-Mexico border better secured than it used to be? Answering this question is complex, and it largely depends on which stretch of the border you consider.
articles.abstract: Is the United States-Mexico border better secured than it used to be? Answering this question is complex, and it largely depends on which stretch of the border you consider.
articles.lead_paragraph: PENITAS, Tex. — The border fence behind Manuel Zamora’s home suggests strength and protection, its steel poles perfectly aligned just beyond the winding Rio Grande. But every night, the crossers come. After dark and at sunup, too, dozens of immigrants scale the wall or walk around it, their arrival announced by the angry yelps of backyard dogs.

articles.headline: Virginia’s Feast on U.S. Funds Nears an End
articles.snippet: The Washington metropolitan area is in line to experience the largest economic hit of any region from the $85 billion in spending cuts that President Obama made official on Friday.
articles.abstract: The Washington metropolitan area is in line to experience the largest economic hit of any region from the $85 billion in spending cuts that President Obama made official on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — To listen to the human side of sequestration, wait in line here for the 595 bus to Reston, Va., a journey across a suburbia grown fat and happy on a federal spending boom in the past decade, primarily military.

articles.headline: Disruptions: As User Interaction on Facebook Drops, Sharing Comes at a Cost
articles.snippet: It seems as if Facebook is not only promoting paid links on news feeds, but also possibly suppressing the ones that aren’t paid for.
articles.abstract: It seems as if Facebook is not only promoting paid links on news feeds, but also possibly suppressing the ones that aren’t paid for.
articles.lead_paragraph: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

articles.headline: Web Privacy Becomes a Business Imperative
articles.snippet: Increasingly, Internet companies like Microsoft, Facebook and Mozilla are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.
articles.abstract: Increasingly, Internet companies like Microsoft, Facebook and Mozilla are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Privacy is no longer just a regulatory headache. Increasingly, Internet companies are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Clings to One Thing It Agrees On: Spending Cuts
articles.snippet: As many Republicans soften their stance on social issues, including same-sex marriage and immigration, the only issue truly uniting the party is a commitment to shrinking government.
articles.abstract: As many Republicans soften their stance on social issues, including same-sex marriage and immigration, the only issue truly uniting the party is a commitment to shrinking government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conservative governors are signing on to provisions of what they once derisively dismissed as Obamacare. Prominent Senate Republicans are taking positions on immigration that would have gotten the party’s presidential candidates hooted off the debate stage during last year’s primaries.

articles.headline: At AMC, Zombies Topple Network TV
articles.snippet: Being a cable network is less of a disadvantage than it used to be, as broadcast networks become just one more click on a seemingly infinite dial.
articles.abstract: Being a cable network is less of a disadvantage than it used to be, as broadcast networks become just one more click on a seemingly infinite dial.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a show about the walking dead on basic cable beats every network show in the ratings demographic that advertisers care most about, you have to wonder who the real zombies are.

articles.headline: One More Trip to Land of Oz
articles.snippet: Disney’s movie studio, which has stumbled recently, takes a bold risk with a prequel to the beloved 1939 musical, “The Wizard of Oz.”
articles.abstract: Disney’s movie studio, which has stumbled recently, takes a bold risk with a prequel to the beloved 1939 musical, “The Wizard of Oz.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Near the middle of “Oz the Great and Powerful,” James Franco, who plays the title character, surveys his bewildering surroundings and mutters “Are you kidding me?”

articles.headline: As Hacking Against U.S. Rises, Experts Try to Pin Down Motive
articles.snippet: Motives for a cyberattack, which could range from industrial spying to disabling the power grid, remain obscure.
articles.abstract: Motives for a cyberattack, which could range from industrial spying to disabling the power grid, remain obscure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Telvent, a company that monitors more than half the oil and gas pipelines in North America, discovered last September that the Chinese had hacked into its computer systems, it immediately shut down remote access to its clients’ systems.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth, David E. Sanger and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Where Apps Meet Work, Secret Data Is at Risk
articles.snippet: Employees who put company information online with their smartphones create a tricky problem for I.T. departments: how to protect corporate data without hindering employees’ work.
articles.abstract: Employees who put company information online with their smartphones create a tricky problem for I.T. departments: how to protect corporate data without hindering employees’ work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As is the case with many busy people, Delyn Simons’s life has become an open phone app of commingled corporate and personal information.

articles.headline: A Jester No More, Italy’s Gadfly of Politics Reflects a Movement
articles.snippet: After a successful showing in last week’s election, Beppe Grillo, a comedian turned activist, is being courted by Italy’s traditional political players, with whom he has refused to play ball.
articles.abstract: After a successful showing in last week’s election, Beppe Grillo, a comedian turned activist, is being courted by Italy’s traditional political players, with whom he has refused to play ball.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — A populist with wild hair, a booming voice and untucked shirts, Beppe Grillo now holds the fate of Italy — and to some extent Europe — in his hands.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Recovery in U.S. Is Lifting Profits, but Not Adding Jobs
articles.snippet: Experts estimate so-called budget sequestration could cost the country about 700,000 jobs, but Wall Street doesn’t expect the cuts to substantially alter corporate profits or threaten stock markets.
articles.abstract: Experts estimate so-called budget sequestration could cost the country about 700,000 jobs, but Wall Street doesn’t expect the cuts to substantially alter corporate profits or threaten stock markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Dow Jones industrial average flirting with a record high, the split between American workers and the companies that employ them is widening and could worsen in the next few months as federal budget cuts take hold.

articles.headline: Banks Find More Wrongful Foreclosures Among Military Members
articles.snippet: Banks uncovered the foreclosures, which eclipse earlier estimates, in an analysis done as part of a multibillion-dollar settlement deal with federal authorities.
articles.abstract: Banks uncovered the foreclosures, which eclipse earlier estimates, in an analysis done as part of a multibillion-dollar settlement deal with federal authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis and seized homes from roughly two dozen other borrowers who were current on their mortgage payments, findings that eclipse earlier estimates of the improper evictions.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Chinese Stocks Plunge on Plan to Tax Home Sales
articles.snippet: China’s cabinet, or State Council, said home sellers would soon pay a 20 percent capital gains tax.
articles.abstract: China’s cabinet, or State Council, said home sellers would soon pay a 20 percent capital gains tax.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Faced with a difficult combination of an economy addicted to cheap credit, exorbitant real estate prices fueled by that credit and mounting public concern that housing is no longer affordable, China’s government is laying plans for steep new taxes on home sellers.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Massacre of Syrian Soldiers in Iraq Raises Risk of Widening Conflict
articles.snippet: More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq were killed on Monday in an ambush, in the most serious spillover of violence into Iraq since the Syrian conflict began.
articles.abstract: More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq were killed on Monday in an ambush, in the most serious spillover of violence into Iraq since the Syrian conflict began.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq from rebel fighters along the border were killed on Monday in an attack by unidentified gunmen as the Iraqi military was transporting the soldiers back to Syria in a bus convoy, the Iraqi government said.
articles.byline: By Duraid Adnan and Rick Gladstone
